text:
Neil is on holiday till the 10th, I have messaged bdp so will keep this thread updated if they reply, my money is that they have released something for the protocol fix.

However the bflw patch seems to be working for me

elements.text:
Neil is on holiday till the 10th, I have messaged bdp so will keep this thread updated if they reply, my money is that they have released something for the protocol fix.

text: Hmmm - so the patch isn't totally working for me, or rather the stream isn't. One of my instances didn't seem to get heartbeats last night and then no data today until I killed and re-started it completely. Others fine.

elements.text: Hmmm - so the patch isn't totally working for me, or rather the stream isn't. One of my instances didn't seem to get heartbeats last night and then no data today until I killed and re-started it completely. Others fine.

text: How do you have this setup? ie. are you using tenacity or another way to restart on error?

elements.text: How do you have this setup? ie. are you using tenacity or another way to restart on error?

text: Tenacity - @retry(etc)

elements.text: Tenacity - @retry(etc)

text: but eventually the socket will timeout

text: Yeah - obviously when it's me there's a high likelihood of a fuck up at my end but this has never failed before.

elements.text: Yeah - obviously when it's me there's a high likelihood of a fuck up at my end but this has never failed before.

text: certainly that on_heartbeat method was only called twice between the conclusion of yesterday's racing and the start of racing today.

elements.text: certainly that on_heartbeat method was only called twice between the conclusion of yesterday's racing and the start of racing today.

text: hmm not sure how that is possilbe

text: I don't do anything to handle the socket timing out, does that raise an exception?

elements.text: I don't do anything to handle the socket timing out, does that raise an exception?

text: yeah timeout, default is 64s so you must have been receiving something through the socket

elements.text: yeah timeout, default is 64s so you must have been receiving something through the socket

text: I have no idea then. All I can say is that I've had everything running this way since that last bunch of problems around June 2023 and I don't think it's failed even once until now.

elements.text: I have no idea then. All I can say is that I've had everything running this way since that last bunch of problems around June 2023 and I don't think it's failed even once until now.

text: ...and like I said, other instances behaved as expected, restarting the stream every five minutes over night.

elements.text: ...and like I said, other instances behaved as expected, restarting the stream every five minutes over night.

text: I wasn't expecting you to - I just thought I'd let you know about it.

elements.text: I wasn't expecting you to - I just thought I'd let you know about it.

text: Yeah certainly running the patch, that instance was behaving as expected for a few days.

elements.text: Yeah certainly running the patch, that instance was behaving as expected for a few days.

text:
Good afternoon everyone!

Guys, do you know the Betfair chart that we can open with the default URL:

"<https://xtsd.betfair.com/LoadRunnerInfoChartAction/?marketId={marketid}&selectionId={selectionid}>"

Well, do you know if there is a limit to the number of charts that I can open and leave updated every 1 second without the risk of being banned or blocked by Betfair (if that even exists)?

I created a local webpage with just the charts of the markets that my automation invested in, but sometimes there may be a lot of investments, which is why I'm afraid that Betfair will block me or something like that.

I decided to ask before continuing to use it.

elements.text:
Good afternoon everyone!

Guys, do you know the Betfair chart that we can open with the default URL:

"

"

Well, do you know if there is a limit to the number of charts that I can open and leave updated every 1 second without the risk of being banned or blocked by Betfair (if that even exists)?

I created a local webpage with just the charts of the markets that my automation invested in, but sometimes there may be a lot of investments, which is why I'm afraid that Betfair will block me or something like that.

I decided to ask before continuing to use it.

text: I didn't even put this page online, it only works together with my Python locally, keeping the graphs according to a CSV file that I have registered the investments that are currently placed on the market.

elements.text: I didn't even put this page online, it only works together with my Python locally, keeping the graphs according to a CSV file that I have registered the investments that are currently placed on the market.

text: Can't you just use the API for this? If not, probably best to ask Betfair for a definitive answer?

elements.text: Can't you just use the API for this? If not, probably best to ask Betfair for a definitive answer?

text: Hi <@UUE6E1LA1> I confess to you that I have already tried to faithfully reproduce the charts, but I could not. I sent here a message about this a few months ago, I tried to reproduce it but it looks very different and I ended up giving up due to lack of knowledge on the subject.

elements.text: Hi

I confess to you that I have already tried to faithfully reproduce the charts, but I could not. I sent here a message about this a few months ago, I tried to reproduce it but it looks very different and I ended up giving up due to lack of knowledge on the subject.

text: I don't use Python myself much but is there really no charting package available? What about ggplot or matplotlib? Is it important to emulate the charts precisely in the way Betfair do?

elements.text: I don't use Python myself much but is there really no charting package available? What about ggplot or matplotlib? Is it important to emulate the charts precisely in the way Betfair do?

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> Yes, there are several packages to help create graphs, but when collecting the values ​​and trying to reproduce the value loads in them, my graphs look very different. It's just a lack of knowledge to be able to combine the API values ​​and generate the graphs. I intend to try again in the future, *including sending the finished code here so that in the future whoever needs it already has it*, but at the moment I'm stuck due to a lack of knowledge.

elements.text: Yes, there are several packages to help create graphs, but when collecting the values ​​and trying to reproduce the value loads in them, my graphs look very different. including sending the finished code here so that in the future whoever needs it already has it
, but at the moment I'm stuck due to a lack of knowledge.

text: The site uses the graph api and some JavaScript, easy to replicate no?

elements.text: The site uses the graph api and some JavaScript, easy to replicate no?

text: Hi <@U4H19D1D2> I didn't know about the existence of the graph api, I tried to recreate the charts using the runner's `totalMatched`. I'm searching here in the documentation about the graph api, but I'm not finding it. Could you help me? (I'm sorry if I might be confusing things)

elements.text: Hi
I didn't know about the existence of the graph api, I tried to recreate the charts using the runner's
totalMatched
. I'm searching here in the documentation about the graph api, but I'm not finding it. Could you help me? (I'm sorry if I might be confusing things)

text: It’s a private api, open up network tab on a graph page and you can see it in action

elements.text: It’s a
private api, open up network tab on a graph page and you can see it in action

text: Oh perfect <@U4H19D1D2>, thank you very much for the information, it's more or less how we found the information regarding the stream of each event that we talked about a few months ago with the intention of adding such information to betfairlightweight!
